newsitem.title: HONG KONG: British heir may sell picture, besides hand over HK.
newsitem.headline: British heir may sell picture, besides hand over HK.

text.p: A Chinese tycoon is negotiating to buy a Hong Kong landscape by British royal heir Prince Charles, a skilled amateur artist, who hands the territory back to China at midnight on June 30.
The pastel-coloured picture depicts a mountain view from the stern of the royal yacht Britannia, with the Union Jack flag fluttering in the centre.
A "very rich" Hong Kong businessman is bargaining for the HK$170,000 (US$22,000) lithograph featured in an exhibition marking the British colony's transition to Beijing rule.
"I think the tycoon wants something to hang in his yacht," the show's organiser Geoffrey Dobbs told Reuters.
In two days, the prince will hand Hong Kong's sovereignty to President Jiang Zemin, ending more than 150 years of Chinese national shame which started with defeat in the Opium Wars.
"The Chinese are not meant to be buying British at the moment, are they?" Dobbs said.
The painting, titled "View of Double Haven from HMY Britannia", was created during the prince's 1989 visit.
"I rather feel that this painting should be entitled "Farewell to Empire" or "Poor Britannia!" the prince was quoted by the organisers as saying.
Two things mark the work from 120 or so others in the "Visions of Hong Kong" show.

For start, it is the most expensive. An ink drawing by Dave Parker lags far behind at HK$100,000. Parker framed his painting of an old junk with wood planks he said came from a boat similar to that in the drawing.
The prince is also the only one, of about 40 artists featured, who does not live in Hong Kong.
Some would add a third difference.
"Really, the painting is the dullest of all," said a photographer. "But for an amateur, it is not bad," Dobbs said.
About 10 of the pieces have been sold by the first day, and Dobbs said he was confident more buyers are in the pipeline.
"But the tycoon is not considering the other paintings because they are all too cheap," Dobbs said.
